description: A tropical fruit tree species belonging to the family Rhamnaceae. The fruit is a drupe, varying in shape from round to oblong, and in size from a cherry to a plum. The flesh is white and crisp.
regions: Parts of Africa and Middle East
healthBenefits: Rich in Vitamin C, boosting immunity and skin health.
Contains antioxidants that help fight free radicals.
Traditionally used for digestive issues and to improve sleep.
Good source of energy due to natural sugars.
cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Thrives in tropical and subtropical climates; drought-resistant.
2. Soil: Adaptable to a wide range of soils, including poor, alkaline, or saline soils, but prefers well-drained sandy loam.
3. Propagation: Usually by seeds, budding, or grafting.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun.
5. Watering: Young plants need regular watering. Mature trees are very drought-tolerant.
6. Fertilizing: Responds well to organic manure. Light fertilization may be needed.
7. Pruning: Prune annually to encourage new growth, as fruits are borne on new shoots.
8. Harvesting: Fruits are harvested when they turn yellowish-green to reddish-brown, depending on variety.
growthDuration: Starts bearing fruit in 2-3 years. Fruits mature in winter to early spring.
sustainabilityTips: Ber can be eaten fresh, dried, or pickled.
Store fresh ber at room temperature for a few days or refrigerate for longer.
Dried ber has a long shelf life.
carbonFootprintInfo: Relatively low, especially if grown locally. (0.3-0.7 kg CO2e/kg)

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Ber (Indian Jujube)
staticRecipes.description: Enjoyed fresh, often with a sprinkle of salt and chili powder.
steps: They can be eaten whole, like a small apple. The skin is edible, and the flesh is crisp around a central stone.
If desired, sprinkle with a little salt and/or red chili powder for a tangy and spicy flavor.

staticRecipes.name: Dried Ber (Sukha Ber)
staticRecipes.description: Ber fruits are often sun-dried for preservation and eaten as a snack.
steps: Spread them on a clean cloth or tray in direct sunlight.
Allow them to dry completely, which may take several days depending on the sun's intensity. Turn them occasionally for even drying.
Once fully dried, they will be shriveled and hard. Store in an airtight container.
Dried ber can be eaten as is or used in traditional preparations.

staticRecipes.name: Ber Pickle (Achar)
staticRecipes.description: A tangy and spicy pickle made from fresh Ber fruits.
ingredients: 1 lb fresh Ber, washed and slit
2 tbsp red chili powder (or to taste)
2 tbsp vinegar (optional, for longer shelf life)
steps: Sun-dry the slit ber fruits for a day or two to remove some moisture.
Dry roast fennel seeds, mustard seeds, and fenugreek seeds separately. Coarsely grind them.
Heat mustard oil in a pan until it smokes lightly, then let it cool completely.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the sun-dried ber, ground spice mixture, turmeric powder, red chili powder, asafoetida, and salt.
Pour the cooled mustard oil over the mixture and mix well.
If using, add vinegar and mix again.
Transfer the pickle to a sterilized, dry glass jar. Cover and keep in the sun for 4-5 days, shaking the jar daily.
The pickle is ready to eat once the ber softens and absorbs the flavors. Store in a cool, dry place.
